_source.name: LocalOccurrenceData

parameters.occurrenceType:
What type data is it? One of 'presence', 
'presence/absence', 'abundance', 'probability'
parameters.columns:
Which columns in the spreadsheet relate to longitude, latitude
and response value? Takes a named character vector e.g.
c(long = 'longitude', lat = 'latitude', value = 'responseVals'). If an
unnamed character vector is given, the order is assumed to be 
long, lat, value.
parameters.filename:
The path to the spreadsheet. The spreadsheet should have a 
header giving column names. The column names should be 'longitude', 'latitude',
and 'value'. 'value' is a numeric such as a proportion, count or presence/absence
(1/0). The file can be .csv, .tab, .tsv, or .xlsx
parameters.externalValidation:
Logical indicating whether this data is external
validation data. Cross validation is handled elsewhere and this argument 
should be left as FALSE for data that will be used in cross validation.

descriptions:
Occurrence module to format local occurrence data to be used with zoon. 
 Must be a .csv file with three columns longitude, latitude and value 
 in that order.

_source.name: QuickGRaF

parameters.l:
lengthscale parameter, a positive number controlling the complexity
of the fitted model with respect to each covariate.
Can either be a single number (in which case it is used for all covariates),
a vector of numbers of the same length as the number of covariates,
or \code{NULL} in which case GRaF will calculate a fixed approximation to
a sensible lengthscale.

descriptions: Model module to fit a quick GRaF model, without parameter optimisation.

_source.name: Bioclim_future

parameters.rcp: numeric. Representative Concentration Pathways, or greenhouse gases concentration trajectories (see \url{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representative_Concentration_Pathways}. Should be one of 26, 45, 60, or 85.
parameters.model: character. General Circulation Model. Should be one of "AC", "BC", "CC", "CE", "CN", "GF", "GD", "GS", "HD", "HG", "HE", "IN", "IP", "MI", "MR", "MC", "MP", "MG", or "NO".
parameters.extent: Length 4 numeric vector giving min longitude, max longitude, min latitude, max latitude.
parameters.layers: which bioclim layers to obtain, a vector of integers between 1 and 19. See \url{http://www.worldclim.org/bioclim}.
parameters.year: numeric. Time period. Should be either 50 (which represents the period 2041-2060) or 70 (which represents the period 2061-2080).
parameters.resolution: Resolution in minutes. Must be one of 2.5, 5 or 10. Default is 10.

descriptions: Get worldclim data for the future (CMIP5). Downloads then stores locally.

_source.name: RandomForest
returnValues: A model object with a valid predict method
descriptions: Model module to fit a simple RandomForest classification model

_source.name: PerformanceMeasures

parameters.threshold:
A chosen threshold value for measures that need 0/1 predictions 
If NULL, the proportion of occurrences in the occurrence data is used.

descriptions: Calculate a suite of performance metrics on either crossvalidation, external validation data or (at your own risk) in-sample validation.

_source.name: BiomodModel

parameters.modelType:
A character to describe models to use. Select from
'GLM','GBM','GAM','CTA','ANN','SRE','FDA','MARS','RF','MAXENT'

descriptions: Model module wrapper for the biomod2 function BIOMOD_Modeling()

_source.name: MaxLike
descriptions: Model module to fit a simple MaxLike model
_source.references:
J.A. Royle, R.B. Chandler, C. Yackulic, and J.D. Nichols (2012). 
  Likelihood analysis of species occurrence probability from presence-only 
  data for modelling species distributions. Methods in Ecology and Evolution,
  3, 545-554.
  
  Hastie, T. & Fithian, W. (2013) Inference from presence-only data; the 
  ongoing controversy. Ecography, 36, 864-867.
  
  Phillips, S.J. & Elith, J. (2013) On estimating probability of presence 
  from use-availability or presence-background data. Ecology, 94, 1409-1419.
  
  Merow, C. & Silander, J.A. (2014) A comparison of Maxlike and Maxent for
  modelling species distributions. Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 5,
  215-225.

_source.name: LocalRaster

parameters.rasters: Either a string of the filename of the raster layer, a list or vector of strings of filenames to rasters that will be stacked, a RasterLayer or a RasterStack object.

descriptions: LocalRaster: Read in a single raster or a list of rasters and stack them.

_source.name: GBM

parameters.max.trees:
The maximum number of trees to fit.
The number of trees is equivalent to the number of iterations and
 the number of basis functions in the additive expansion. The optimal
 number will be selected by cross-validation, but this sets an upper limit.
parameters.interaction.depth:
The maximum depth of variable interactions.
1 implies an additive model, 2 implies a model with up to 2-way interactions,
 etc.
parameters.shrinkage:
a shrinkage parameter applied to each tree in the expansion.
Also known as the learning rate or step-size reduction.

descriptions:
Model module to fit a generalized boosted regression (aka boosted regression
trees) model

_source.name: Transform

parameters.replace: a logical, determining whether to overwrite the values of the named layers with the transformed values (if \code{replace = TRUE}), or to add extra layers with the transformed covariates. If additional layers are added, they will be renamed accoring to the \code{raster} package's renaming conventions. This normally involves adding a '.2' at the end of the name.
parameters.trans: a function defining a transformation to apply to each pixel in the covariate(s) raster. This can be a definition (e.g. \code{function(x) x^2} for a square) or a function defined in base R (e.g. \code{log1p} for the log(x + 1) transformation). The default transformation does nothing.#'
parameters.which_cov: a character vector naming all of the covariates in the RasterStack to which the new transformation should be applied.#'

descriptions: Apply a tranformation function (e.g. square, log, something else) to one or more covariates, pixelwise. These can either overwrite the named covariates, or be added to the covariate set.

_source.name: MyMaxLike
descriptions: Model module to fit a simple MyMaxLike model
_source.references:
J.A. Royle, R.B. Chandler, C. Yackulic, and J.D. Nichols (2012). 
  Likelihood analysis of species occurrence probability from presence-only 
  data for modelling species distributions. Methods in Ecology and Evolution,
  3, 545-554.
  
  Hastie, T. & Fithian, W. (2013) Inference from presence-only data; the 
  ongoing controversy. Ecography, 36, 864-867.
  
  Phillips, S.J. & Elith, J. (2013) On estimating probability of presence 
  from use-availability or presence-background data. Ecology, 94, 1409-1419.
  
  Merow, C. & Silander, J.A. (2014) A comparison of MyMaxlike and Maxent for
  modelling species distributions. Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 5,
  215-225.

_source.name: CarolinaWrenPO
descriptions: Occurrence locations for the Carolina Wren \emph{Thryothorus ludovicianus} at Breeding Bird Survey transects in 2006. These data are made available in the maxlike R package. See \code{\link[maxlike]{carw.data}} for more details, and see the module \code{CarolinaWrenPA} for the presence-absence version. This module loads the data, drops absence data, transforms the coordinates to lat/longs and formats the data for use in a zoon workflow.

_source.name: UKBioclim
descriptions:
Load Bioclim rasters at 5 degree resolution for the UK
	(extent \code{c(-10, 10, 45, 65)}).

_source.name: Bootstrap

parameters.n: the number of points to sample. Defaults to the same number as the dataset

descriptions:
Process module to generate random bootstraps of the 
  data.

_source.name: UKAnophelesPlumbeus
descriptions:
Return some Anopheles plumbeus data that is bundled with package.
 Data taken from GBIF and has the extent \code{c(-10, 10, 45, 65)}.

_source.name: Crossvalidate

parameters.k: Positive integer number of folds to split the data into. Default is 5.

descriptions: Run k fold crossvalidation. If presence absence, split presences and absences separately so folds have equally balanced data. Otherwise just sample.

_source.name: BackgroundAndCrossvalid

parameters.k: The number of folds you wish to have. Will later implement a leaveoneout opt

descriptions:
Process module to generate up to 100 background records at random in
     cells of ras and split all data in k folds for cross validation.

_source.name: OneHundredBackground
descriptions:
Process module to generate up to 100 background records at random in
     cells of ras and return these along with the presence only data.

_source.name: NaiveRandomPresenceAbsence

parameters.extent: A numeric vector of length 4 giving the coordinates of the rectangular region within which to create the random points. order: xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax. By default the extent of the UK.
parameters.seed: Used with set.seed to set a seed. Default NULL, no seed is used
parameters.pAbs: The proportion of records that should be absences (default: 0.5)
parameters.n: Numeric - the number of points to create

descriptions: Creates a random occurrence dataset within the extent given

_source.name: SpOcc

parameters.limit: The maximum number of occurrence records to return.
parameters.species:
A character string giving the species name.
e.g. 'Anopheles plumbeus'.
parameters.extent:
A numeric vector of length 4 giving the coordinates of the 
rectangular region within which to carry out the analysis, in the 
order: xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax.
parameters.databases:
A character vector giving the databases to use.
Choose from "gbif", "bison", "inat", "ebird", "ecoengine", "antweb".
Defaults to gbif. NB I have had some problems with databases other
than gbif.
parameters.type:
A string giving the type of occurrence data to treat these records as.
Must be one of \code{'presence'} (the default and most common use case),
\code{'absence'} or \code{'background'} (which may be used to implement
a 'target background group' approach for overcoming observation bias).

descriptions: Occurrence module to collect occurrence data from a number of data bases.

_source.name: SurfaceMap

parameters.dir: Directory where plots are saved. If NULL (default) then plots are not saved.

descriptions: Make a png of a map of predicted surface.

_source.name: NaiveRandomPresence

parameters.extent: A numeric vector of length 4 giving the coordinates of the rectangular region within which to create the random points. order: xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax. By default the extent of the UK.
parameters.seed: Used with set.seed to set a seed. Default NULL, no seed is used
parameters.n: Numeric - the number of points to create

descriptions: Creates a random occurrence dataset within the extent given

_source.name: Clean

parameters.which: A numeric or character vector describing which data cleaning processes to use (see details).

descriptions: Do some data cleaning on occurrence points

_source.name: MaxEnt

parameters.args:
Additional arguments to pass to MaxEnt to modify model fitting,
in the form of flags to the java executable.
Unfortunately these are a bit cryptic and the maxent
help files, which list all of the options, aren't available on the web.
You could try the MaxEnt graphical user interface, otherwise there is a list
(which may or may not be up-to-date) in this forum:
\url{https://groups.google.com/d/msg/maxent/yRBlvZ1_9rQ/Fj8Two0lmHIJ}.

descriptions: Model module to fit MaxEnt model via the dismo package

_source.name: NATrees

parameters.dateRange: Optional 2-item numeric vector giving the years to use; default is the full range of the data (1960-2013)
parameters.species: Which species should be extracted, with format genus_species (all lowercase); allowable values are: abies_balsamea acer_rubrum acer_saccharum betula_alleghaniensis betula_papyrifera fagus_grandifolia fraxinus_americana fraxinus_nigra larix_laricina picea_glauca picea_mariana picea_rubens pinus_banksiana pinus_resinosa pinus_strobus populus_grandidentata populous_tremuloides quercus_macrocarpa quercus_rubra thuja_occidentalis tsuga_canadensis

descriptions: Retrieves occurrences for 21 trees from eastern North America. Data originally sourced from USGS FIA forest inventory database, collected in the QUICC-FOR project ($URL). This dataset was originally published in $REF. Extent for this dataset is c(-97,-67,25,50)

_source.name: OneThousandBackground
descriptions:
Process module to generate up to 1000 background records at random in
     cells of the covariate raster and return these along with the occurrence data.

_source.name: CarolinaWrenPA
descriptions: Presence/absence of the Carolina Wren \emph{Thryothorus ludovicianus} at Breeding Bird Survey transects in 2006. These data are made available in the maxlike R package. See \code{\link[maxlike]{carw.data}} for more details. This module loads them data transform the coordinates to lat/longs and formats the data for use in a zoon workflow.

_source.name: Appify

parameters.run_App: Logical, should the app be run automatically. Not recommended for workflows containing lists. Default is FALSE
parameters.directory: (Optional) a string giving the path to a directory within which to save the shiny app. This directory must exist.#'

descriptions: The Appify module builds a shiny app that displays dynamic graphical and tabular representations of the input data (occurrence and covarite) as well as model predictions.

_source.name: VariableImportance

parameters.print: If true then the data are returned to console as well as outputted

descriptions: This module outputs a simple report of the coefficents/importance measures from the model

_source.name: LogisticRegression
descriptions: Model module to fit a simple logistic regression model

_source.name: CarolinaWrenRasters
descriptions: Land cover and coordinate covariate data for the USA, used in the Carolina Wren MaxLike analysis. These data are made available in the maxlike R package. See \code{\link[maxlike]{carw.data}} for more details, and see the modules \code{CarolinaWrenPA} and \code{CarolinaWrenPO} for corresponding occurrence data. This module loads the data, converts them into a \code{RasterStack} object and transforms the coordinates to lat/longs.

_source.name: addInteraction

parameters.exclude: For option 'pairs', exclude the covariates named from interactions.
parameters.which_covs: List with vector(s) of names of covariates to interact, e.g. list(c('A', 'C', 'D')), or 'pairs' for all pairwise interactions.

descriptions: The module constructs new covariates torepresent interactions (and possibly polynomial terms).

_source.name: ROCcurve

parameters.newwin: logical indicator (default: true) to specify whether the plot should be made in a new window

descriptions: The module retrieves output from a presence only, or presence-absence model and outputs an ROC-curve with the AUC-value above it  it uses the evaluate function from dismo.

_source.name: JitterOccurrence

parameters.sd: standard deviation of the gaussian noise to add the the coordinates of each ocurrence record

descriptions: Often the geographic coordinates of occurrence records are subject to uncertainty. One approach ot accounting for that uncertainty in an SDM analysis is to run several analyses, each time sampling a different location from a probability distribution over the likely "true" coordinates. \code{JitterOccurrence} generates one such sample, under an assumption that the distribution is an isotropic Gaussian with standard deviation \code{sd}

_source.name: PartitionDisc

parameters.buffer: Numeric, the size of the buffer zone in degrees
parameters.radius: Numeric the radius of the disc, in degrees

descriptions: This process module partitions the sample into training and tests set by selecting circular test areas (possibly surrounded by an exclusion buffer) and using the remaining samples as training samples. See function partition.disc in package sperrorest for more details

_source.name: OptGRaF
descriptions: Model module to fit a (slow) GRaF model, with parameter optimisation.

_source.name: StandardiseCov

parameters.exclude: Variable names of numeric variables to exclude from standardisation
parameters.Gelman: Option to divide by two rather than one standard deviation.

descriptions: The module by default scales all numeric covariates. By default conducts a regular standardisation: minus the mean and divide by the standard deviation. If Gelman = TRUE then divides by 2 sd as suggested by Gelman. Excluded covariates are not standardised.

_source.name: Lorem_ipsum_UK
descriptions: The module retrieves a dataset ofLorem ipsum records from figshare. This dataset containsprecence only data and was collected between 1990 and2000 by members of to Lorem ipsum appreciation society

_source.name: mgcv

parameters.bs:
a two letter character string indicating the (penalized)
smoothing basis to use. (eg "tp" for thin plate regression spline,
 "cr" for cubic regression spline). See \code{\link{mgcv::smooth.terms}}
 for an overview of what is available.
parameters.k:
the dimension of the basis used to represent the smooth term.
The default depends on the number of variables that the smooth is a
 function of. k should not be less than the dimension of the null space
  of the penalty for the term (see \code{\link{mgcv::null.space.dimension}}),
  but will be reset if it is. See \code{\link{mgcv::choose.k}} for further
  information

descriptions:
Model module to fit a generalized additive model using generalized
crossvalidation via the mgcv R package.

_source.name: InteractiveMap
descriptions:
Plot a zoomable and scrollable map of the predicted distribution
and training data. Clicking on a point reveals additional information.

_source.name: PredictNewRasterMap

parameters.newraster: Raster* object to make predictions onto.
parameters.extent: Numeric vector of length 4 giving (in this order) the min x, max x, min y, max y, the the new area to be mapped. Must be within the covariate data collected in the covariate module.
parameters.plot: Logical, if \code{TRUE} (default) the prediction map is plotted.

descriptions: Output module. Predict a model across a new area or time period.

_source.name: SugarMaple
descriptions: Presence/absence of Sugar Maple (\emph{Acer saccharum}) in North America. Each record corresponds to the centroid of a 0.5 degree cell.

_source.name: NCEP

parameters.status.bar: Logical. Should a status bar be shown indicating the percentage of completion?
parameters.extent:
A numeric vector of length 4 giving the coordinates of the 
rectangular region within which to carry out the analysis, in the 
order: xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax.
parameters.variables:
Character vector of which variables to select.
See NCEP.gather for more options but basic options are
      *'air'*    Air Temperature                 deg K    
      *'hgt'*    Geopotential Height             m        
      *'rhum'*   Relative Humidity               %        
      *'shum'*   Specific Humidity               kg/kg    
      *'omega'*  Omega [Vertical Velocity]       Pascal/s 
      *'uwnd'*   U-Wind Component [East/West]    m/s      
      *'vwnd'*   V-Wind Component [North/South]  m/s

descriptions: Covariate module to grab coarse resolution environmental data from NCEP

_source.name: NoProcess
returnValues:
a Raster object (class from the raster package) with the gridded
     covariates used to train and predict from the SDM.
descriptions:
Process module that does nothing. A place holder for if nothing should be
done to the data before modelling.

_source.name: NBNdataByName

parameters.silent: if TRUE information returned to console is reduced
parameters.VC: a string giving a vice-county name (see listVCs in the rnbn package)
parameters.species: The latin name of a species to search for, or a vector of such names.
parameters.acceptTandC: if set to TRUE you accept the NBN gateway terms and conditions and privacy policy. These can be found at https://data.nbn.org.uk/Terms. Accepting the terms and conditions supresses the corresponding warning message.
parameters.datasets: a list of dataset keys which are strings of 8 alphanumeric characters. Look up datasets here: https://data.nbn.org.uk/Datasets
parameters.gridRef: a string giving a UK gridreference in which to search for occurrences
parameters.attributes: if FALSE then attribute data is not returned, this may improve the speed of large requests.
parameters.group: a string giving the name of a group (see listGroups in the rnbn package). Using group will retireve data for all TVKs in this group. for example using group "reptile" will search using over 150 TVKs including TVKs for higher taxonomic groups such families within reptiles. Therefore it may be preferrable to search using a vector of species

descriptions: This module supplies occurrence data from the UK NBN gateway. To get access to data you must first register at https://data.nbn.org.uk/User/Register. You will need your username and password when running this module. You can specify the data to retrieve by dataset, species, time, location and/or group.

_source.name: ResponseCurveViz
descriptions: Basic conditional plots in one column

_source.name: StochasticLogisticRegression
descriptions: Fits a simple logistic regression model, but then samples a single draw of the model coefficients (with probability proportional to their likelihood) and uses these for future prediction

_source.name: SameTimePlaceMap
returnValues:
A Raster object giving the probabilistic model predictions for each
     cell of ras
descriptions: Output module. A function for outputing the raster of the predictions from an analysis

_source.name: Bioclim

parameters.extent: Length 4 numeric vector giving min longitude, max longitude, min latitude, max latitude.
parameters.layers: which bioclim layers to obtain, a vector of integers between 1 and 19.
parameters.resolution: Resolution in minutes. Must be one of 2.5, 5 or 10. Default is 10.

descriptions: Get worldclim environment data. Downloads then stores locally.

_source.name: NoOutput
descriptions: No output is created

_source.name: ResponseCurve

parameters.cov:
which of the covariates to plot the response against.
If \code{NULL}, the function is executed for all covariates, one after another.
Else it should be a single numeric identifying the covariate to plot.

descriptions:
Plot a detailed conditional response curve from the model
against one covariate.

_source.name: InteractiveCovariateMap

parameters.which:
which covariate to plot.
A single numeric giving the index of the covariate to plot

descriptions: Plot a zoomable and scrollable map of a covariate layer.

_source.name: CWBZimbabwe
descriptions:
Presence/absence survey data for the coffee white stem borer
 in Zimbabwe.

_source.name: NaiveRandomRaster

parameters.res: Numeric giving the resolution of the raster to produce. 1 is one cell per degree, 0.5 means one cell per half degree.
parameters.extent: A numeric vector of length 4 giving the coordinates of the rectangular region within which to create the raaster. order: xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax. By default the extent of the UK
parameters.seed: Used with set.seed to set a seed. Default NULL, no seed is used

descriptions: Creates a random raster layer within the extent given

_source.name: MESSMask
descriptions:
Calculate the multivariate environmental similarity surface 
  and mask areas with values outside the range of variability in the 
  training region.

_source.name: AnophelesPlumbeus

parameters.extent:
A numeric vector of length 4 giving the coordinates of the 
rectangular region within which to carry out the analysis, in the 
order: xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax. By default the extent of the UK.

descriptions:
Occurrence module to grab *Anopheles plumbeus* (a mosquito) presence
      (presence-only) data from GBIF, in the area bounded by extent.

_source.name: PrintMap

parameters.res: The output resolution in ppi when writing to a png file.
parameters.dir:
Directory where plots are saved. If \code{NULL} (default) then plots are
not saved.
parameters.points: If \code{TRUE} the training points will be plotted over the prediction surface
parameters.size: A vector containing the width and height of the output figure when writing to a png file. Example: c(800,600).
parameters.plot: If \code{TRUE} the plot will be displayed in the device

returnValues:
A Raster object giving the probabilistic model predictions for each
cell of covariate raster layer
descriptions: Plot a map of predicted surface.

_source.name: Background

parameters.n: the number of background points to sample
parameters.bias:
optional \code{RasterLayer} with cells giving the relative
probability of a background record being sampled there. Alternatively,
a length one numeric giving a radius (in KM) around presence points to take 
background points from. If \code{bias = NULL} (the default) then no 
biasing is applied, and all non-missing cells are equally likely to be selected.

descriptions:
Process module to generate random (optionally biased) background
  records in cells of the covariate raster and return these along with the
  presence only data.

_source.name: MachineLearn

parameters.metric:
a string that specifies what summary metric will be used to
select the optimal model. Options are "ROC", "Accuracy" and
"Kappa".
parameters.tuneGrid:
Explicitely pass a data frame of tuning/hyperparameter combinations. If
NULL, tuneLength will be used instead.
parameters.number: How many folds to use in cross validation.
parameters.tuneLength: How many values of each tuning/hyperparameter should be tried?
parameters.method:
The machine learning method to use. Common examples are "glm", 
"nnet", "gbm", "glmnet", "rf". See 
http://topepo.github.io/caret/modelList.html for a full list. Only 
classification or dual use models are useable.
parameters.repeats:
How many times should the entire cross validation process be 
repeated. Increasing this will reduce instability in your model performace,
but will take longer to run.
parameters.trControl:
A named list of further arguments to pass to trainControl. See 
\code{\link[caret]{trainControl}} for details.

descriptions: Model module to fit a very large number of machine learning models.

_source.name: AirNCEP

parameters.quiet: Logical. If TRUE (default) the progress of downloads is not shown

descriptions:
Covariate module to grab a coarse resolution mean air temperature raster from
 January-February 2001-2002 for the UK.

_source.name: SeparatePA
descriptions: The module retrieves output from a presence-absence model and outputs a simple figure with kernel-density estimated histrograms (left) and a boxplot (right).

_source.name: UKAir
descriptions: Return some UK air temperature data from NCEP. Data is bundled with package and has the extent \code{c(-10, 10, 45, 65)}.
